title: Part A
descriptions: The response does not correctly describe an economic force that encourages people to move into metropolitan areas.

The response correctly describes ONE of the following economic forces that encourages people to move into metropolitan areas:

• Access to employment opportunities

• Higher wage opportunities

• New business opportunities

• Housing opportunities

• Access to communications and utility infrastructure

title: Part B
descriptions: The response does not correctly explain a reason why suburbanization occurs in the United States and Canada.

The response correctly explains ONE of the following reasons why suburbanization occurs in the United States and Canada:

• Development of commuter train lines allows people working in city center to live outside of the city.

• Development of highways allow car owners to live in the urban periphery and work in other locations.

• Economic decline in city centers motivates working-class, middle-class, or upper-class residents to move from the central city to the suburbs as they seek local amenities or higher quality public services in suburban communities.

• Land costs are lower on the urban periphery, making housing more affordable for new workers, migrants, or first-time home buyers

title: Part C
descriptions: The response does not correctly explain a reason why gentrification occurs in the United States and Canada.

The response correctly explains ONE of the following reasons why gentrification occurs in the United States and Canada:

Property owners reinvest in or renovate an existing residential and/or commercial building because the structure (or neighborhood) for the following reasons:

• If sold, the renovated building would result in a significant return on investment for the owners.

• The building or neighborhood has architectural or aesthetic value and, if renovated, the building would attract home buyers.

• The building or neighborhood is located near a growth pole (e.g., university, government center, hospital, research center, or new business center).

• The building or neighborhood is located near a cultural center (e.g., arts center, arts district, performance hall, park, historical location, historical district, or traditionally ethnic neighborhood).

• The building or neighborhood is located along new transit lines, bikeable or walkable trails or lanes, greenways (rails to trails), or waterways (docklands, quays).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
One point for a correct explanation

The response must have one rural AND one urban explanation of impact.
descriptions: The response does not correctly compare gentrification and suburbanization in terms of the socioeconomic impacts on an area’s original residents.

The response correctly compares gentrification and suburbanization in terms of ONE of the following impacts on rural areas and ONE of the following impacts on urban areas:

Rural residents own or rent land or farmland that rises in value. This results in a loss of the agricultural or rural way of life for the following reasons:

• As suburbs grow closer to farms, land is sold to developers because of opportunity for economic gain.

• As suburbs grow closer to farms, land is sold due to prohibitive increases in property taxes.

• Tenant farmers cannot afford higher rents and must move off of land.

Urban area residents or business people own or rent a property or commercial space. This results in a loss of homes or business locations or potential homelessness or business closures for the following reasons:

• Housing or commercial space is closed for reconstruction.

• Gentrified housing or commercial space is sold for economic gain.

• Local homeowners and business owners cannot afford higher property taxes.

• Tenants cannot afford higher rents and are forced to move to lower-cost locations.

title: Part E
descriptions: The response does not correctly explain how gentrified neighborhoods or areas of new urbanism redevelopment can affect the larger metropolitan area’s housing economy.

The response correctly explains how gentrified neighborhoods or areas of new urbanism redevelopment can affect the larger metropolitan area’s housing economy using ONE of the following:

• Baseline property values or rents increase across the city, making housing costs or the cost of running a business more expensive, and/or in many cases, prohibitive for local residents who must move out of the area.

• Socioeconomic housing patterns change as some middle- or upper-class residents move into urban neighborhoods where they previously did not live.

• New housing development is focused in gentrified or new urbanism areas while other urban areas remain economically underdeveloped.

• Transit development is focused in gentrified or new urbanism areas while other urban areas remain underserviced by public transit.

title: Part F
descriptions: The response does not correctly describe a way redevelopment using new urbanism changes the population density of a city.

The response correctly describes ONE of the following ways that redevelopment using new urbanism changes the population density of a city:

Population density increases as a result of the following:

• Housing is integrated within commercial areas or zoned as mixed-use developments.

• New development increases the number of housing units per block.

• Former large industrial sites with no population are converted to housing.

title: Part G
descriptions: The response does not correctly explain a reason that people may desire to migrate away from metropolitan areas.

The response correctly explains ONE of the following reasons that people may desire to migrate away from metropolitan areas to rural areas:

• Rural areas offer large plots of land at relatively low cost per acre compared to cities and suburbs for construction of a new home.

• Rural areas are increasingly accessible to the internet and digital cellular phone service, allowing telecommuters to live and work remotely.

• Rural areas have reduced environmental stressors, such as traffic, pollution, noise, and light, and, as a result, living in rural areas improves quality of life.

• Rural areas have agricultural land available for those who prefer to supply their own food and materials for home use.

• Rural areas have agricultural land available for those who prefer to engage in commercial agriculture.
